What funding gaps exist for water infrastructure and services in Africa, and what are the primary financing sources?

African countries face a large funding gap for water and sanitation investments, needing about USD 22 billion yearly but currently spending USD 8-13 billion. Funding primarily comes from tariffs, government subsidies, and some international aid, with substantial scope to improve efficiency and mobilize commercial finance.[Source: Water Governance in african countries.pdf]

What is the state of national and local water policies in African countries and cities?

Around two-thirds of African countries have formally approved national water and sanitation policies, many with national implementation plans. Likewise, about three-quarters of surveyed cities have adopted local dedicated water and sanitation policies, though far fewer have explicit local water resources policies. Local policies often include social measures for vulnerable populations but may lack required resources and monitoring mechanisms to be fully effective.[Source: Water Governance in african countries.pdf]
